title: Metabolomics and Cellular Metabolism
content: Research focuses on a quantitative, comprehensive understanding of cellular metabolism, through the study of metabolites and their fluxes. This includes a conversation around glucose, glucose metabolism, lactate as a fuel, movement of lactate and the regulation of these substrates. There is also a detailed discussion on the electronic transport chain and the Krebs cycle and what the implications are, both with respect to drugs and nutrition.

title: NAD and its Precursors
content: The discussion includes the intravenous use of NAD and the oral use of the precursors. There are more questions about the NAD precursors: NR and NMN. There is a significant point made about something that has been misunderstood about this topic.

title: Cancer Metabolism
content: The conversation ends with a discussion about cancer metabolism. Particularly one way in which cancer metabolism and immunotherapy might intersect.

title: Metabolomics 101: Defining Metabolites and How They Are Regulated
content: Metabolism is the process that converts the food we eat into usable energy and the building blocks our body needs to grow or regenerate itself, as well as waste along the way. Metabolomics is the study of these processes. The bulk of metabolism involves something like a hundred metabolites. Examples of metabolites include all the amino acids and other fundamental inputs we get from our diet, intermediary metabolites, and more effector or energy-holding metabolites like ATP, NADH, NADPH.

title: Regulation of Metabolites
content: The pH spectrum runs from 0 to 14, with neutral pH being 7. The human body is tightly regulated to keep us at a pH of 7-7.7. Many important metabolites live in a 2-3 fold range as being the preferred range. For some metabolites, there is a lot more active regulation (like glucose), while for others, there is a relatively passive process that keeps them in that range. The most important principle in regulating metabolites is: When it’s there, use it up. A lot of what you eat, after a little bit of processing, enters the bloodstream. Then it’s the job of the tissues that need these ingredients to use them, in proportion to their availability in the blood.

title: Role of Insulin in Metabolite Regulation
content: The most important regulatory hormone in mammals is insulin. Insulin acts to control elevations in blood sugar by promoting uptake of glucose and preventing production of glucose. Insulin also signals that there are enough carbohydrates around and therefore, it’s safe to not release fat from your adipose tissue. Insulin has two equally important roles: the disposal of glucose into muscle and stopping glucose production in the liver, and stopping lipolysis to keep fat in your fat stores.

title: Fluxomics: Metabolism as a System in Action
content: Metabolites are intermediates in the process of converting what we eat into usable energy and protein biomass. These things are relatively low in abundance and they’re flowing very fast. Metabolites are meant to be made and used on a timescale of a second to an hour (depending on the metabolite).

title: Regulation and Flow of Blood Glucose
content: A healthy blood glucose level is around 89 mg/dL. That glucose has to be constantly replenished in order to feed tissues that depend on glucose such as your brain, activated immune cells, and other tissues. Type 2 diabetes more than doubles your risk of mortality and increases your risk of cancer, Alzheimer’s disease, and cardiovascular disease. This disease becomes a problem with only a 2-fold increase in blood glucose levels.

title: The Randle Hypothesis: Glucose and Fatty Acids Competition
content: There’s a competition between the fuels glucose and fat; this is a very old idea called the Randle Hypothesis. A lot of tissues make room for glucose to be burned by controlling the amount of fat that’s being used by tissues. When fat is available, then glucose tends not to be burned effectively; and that’s a possible cause of diabetes.

title: The Important Role of Lactate as an Alternate Fuel
content: When your demand for ATP gets high enough and quick enough, you’re going to basically take glucose and when you turn it into pyruvate, rather than take the efficient path of shuttling pyruvate into Acetyl-CoA through the Krebs Cycle, where you can generate lots of ATP (requiring oxygen), you convert glucose to lactate. This is a quicker path that’s less efficient, but doesn’t require the same cellular oxygen, and you won’t get nearly as much ATP. This also tends to generate a lot of lactate, which tends to gravitate with hydrogen ions, which tends to poison the muscle a little bit. That’s why it becomes rate limiting, in terms of how long you can sustain that level of output.

title: Glucose and Lactate Levels
content: There is a much bigger range in blood lactate levels. The levels probably depend a lot on your physiological state. Lactate is a very flexible metabolite; it goes down very quickly. Too much lactate in the blood can cause medical problems like lactic acidosis. This can occur with certain metabolic deficiencies or if you couldn’t breathe, then you end up in this crisis of redox imbalance.

title: Neurons and Lactate
content: Neurons might like lactate beside glucose. Normally, neurons exclusively used glucose. In the ‘60s, it was shown they could use ketone bodies, beta-hydroxybutyrate and acetoacetate. Neurons could use maybe 60/40 in favor of ketone bodies to glucose. There were whisperings in animal studies that suggested neurons could consume lactate. There is certainly lactate use in the brain. This is an active area of investigation.

title: Lactate as a Fuel
content: Lactate allows a tremendous degree of flexibility that wouldn’t exist otherwise. Lactate is used throughout the whole body. There is an evolutionary reason for allowing most tissues to use lactate directly as a fuel instead of relying on the liver to mop it up. The system would be way less flexible if only the liver could clean this up. It would also be way less commensurate with effective bursts of exercise.

title: Fasting Lactate Levels and Metabolic Dysfunction
content: Fasting lactate levels could be a potential early indicator of metabolic dysfunction. There seems to be a correlation between fasting glucose and fasting lactate. When fasting lactate is high, it reflects the fact that during these times of fasting, when glucose is not really supposed to be used much, you’re still using too much glucose. You’re converting too much glucose to lactate. At the same time that your lactate clearance system isn’t working very well. Typically, that’s because you’re having competition between lactate and fat to be burned.

title: The Krebs Cycle and Energy Production
content: The Krebs cycle is fundamental to energy production. You eat 3 macronutrients: carbs, protein and fat. In a healthy adult, every carbon atom that you eat in any of those three forms needs to exit your body as exhaled carbon dioxide. All of that exhaled carbon dioxide is made in the TCA cycle (aka the Krebs cycle). The main way that nutrients flow into the TCA cycle to become carbon dioxide is first turning into pieces that are 2-carbon units in size. The Krebs cycle is probably 3x as important as anything else in metabolism.
